review.title: Argotario: Computational Argumentation Meets Serious Games
review.abstract: An important skill in critical thinking and argumentation is the ability to spot and recognize fallacies. Fallacious arguments, omnipresent in argumentative discourse, can be deceptive, manipulative, or simply leading to `wrong moves' in a discussion. Despite their importance, argumentation scholars and NLP researchers with focus on argumentation quality have not yet investigated fallacies empirically. The nonexistence of resources dealing with fallacious argumentation calls for scalable approaches to data acquisition and annotation, for which the serious games methodology offers an appealing, yet unexplored, alternative. We present Argotario, a serious game that deals with fallacies in everyday argumentation. Argotario is a multilingual, open-source, platform-independent application with strong educational aspects, accessible at www.argotario.net.

metadata.title: Argotario: Computational Argumentation Meets Serious Games

sections.text: An important skill in critical thinking and reasoning is the ability to detect and recognize errors. Misleading arguments, which are ubiquitous in argumentative discourse, can be misleading, manipulative, or simply "wrong steps" in a discussion. Despite their importance, argumentationists and NLP researchers focusing on reasoning quality have not yet empirically investigated errors. The absence of resources devoted to misleading reasoning requires scalable approaches to data collection and commentary, for which serious game methodology offers an attractive but as yet unexplored alternative. We present Argotario, a serious game that addresses errors in everyday reasoning. Argotario is a multilingual, open source application with strong educational aspects that is available at www.argotario.net.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: While understanding the structure of an argument is unfortunately the predominant task of reasoning Mining / computational argumentation (Mochales and Moens, 2011; Stab and Gurevych, 2014; Habernal and Gurevych, 2017), a parallel strand of research attempts to evaluate qualitative properties of arguments (Habernal and Gurevych, 2016b; Stab and Gurevych, 2017). However, the gap between theories and everyday reasoning, in understanding what "argumentative quality" actually is, remains an open research question (Wachsmuth et al., 2017; Habernal and Gurevych, 2016a) argumentation theories and critical thinking textbooks offer an alternative view of the quality of arguments, namely the notion of fallacies: prototypical arguments or types that pretend to be correct and valid arguments but suffer logically, emotionally or rhetorically.

sections.text: The first study of early versions of Argotario examined the impact of hard feedback and its absence on overall engagement of users in the game. We found that soft feedback did not have a significant negative impact on user experiences8 (Hannemann, 2015).In a subsequent study, we examined player levels using Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT).We asked workers to play a special version of Argotario (20 and 17 participants, respectively) with the same game configuration, but either with soft or hard feedback; final questionnaire with Likert scale questions; Mann-Whitney-U non-parametric test.Configured version of Argotario to "win" 20 points needed to submit HIT. Since the player against the player requires two rounds of dialogue from two users and thus two or more people actively participating in the interpretation over a longer period of time, we should quickly match this naive game for a larger audience with the same unpaid game with the same number of media in 2016.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text: Argotario is a serious game that serves several purposes. First, it is a software tool for computer-aided linguistic research, since it focuses on fallacies in argumentative discourse, an important part of qualitative criteria in computer-aided reasoning. Second, it is software that supports learning and education. Its main educational purpose is to raise awareness - not only that fallacies exist, but that they can easily be overlooked and misused in everyday reasoning. Finally, Argotario is also a data collection and annotation tool that applies successful crowdsourced quality estimation techniques. All content is created by users within the game, as opposed to common annotation tools. In the long run, we expect Argotario to provide a viable method of data collection compared to standard crowdsourcing.
